--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
> Is DevCreek =
anything like what you're looking for?
> 
> On 8/27/07, kirkandsheila <kirk=
@...> wrote:
> > Hi all,
> >
> > I'm doing some research to determine what =
products/projects are out
> > there to perform historical/statistical/trend=
 analysis on JUnit
> > results. Ideally, I'd like to be able to break down =
the JUnit results
> > that can be filtered, aggregated, and so forth for re=
ports.

Kirk, DevCreek can show a detailed review of the past day's testing=

and also historical charts with trending information. The complete
history=
 of test run and test method executions are recorded for each
developer on =
the team. Every test run inside of the developer's IDE is
recorded rather t=
han just those triggered by the build process after
check-in. We have an Ec=
lipse Java plug-in ready for use with JUnit,
and a web API to collect JUnit=
 or other metrics from outside of
Eclipse. We would be happy to work with y=
ou if you are using JUnit
from an alternative IDE or text editor. If you ar=
e happy sharing your
data with the community then the service is free to us=
e.

http://devcreek.com

You can get detailed feedback on your recent testi=
ng either in Eclipse
or on the website. We present each executed test run, =
whether it was
successful or not and the number of tests involved. This can=
 help you
to become more aware of how you are testing, alert you when you a=
re
straying from your preferred behaviour (for example when you are lost
in=
 the debugger for hours on end rather than writing a new test), or
act as a=
 measure for adopting a new testing style. We also show some
simple heurist=
ics and a list of added test methods. The intention is
that this data can f=
eed back into your own and your team's learning
practices.

I haven't done =
much coding the last few days, but feel free to get an
idea of the recorded=
 activity by looking at the DevCreek project
itself (TestCreek is an earlie=
r project name for DevCreek):

Project activity: https://devcreek.com/proje=
ct/TestCreek

My own testing activity:
https://devcreek.com/principalActivi=
ty/TestCreek/DGJ

The other side is historical charts. We keep a history of=
 the test
executions for the entire duration of the project. We have number=
 of
built-in reports that 

cover a range of testing analyses. For example =
total test methods,
frequency of test run 

executions, test durations, res=
ults and so on. We also have some
reports that get closer to 

quality and =
process measures such as time taken to fix broken tests,
the cost for addin=
g a 

new test method (by number of executed tests/new test method), testin=
g
by hour-of-day or 

day-of-week and so on.

Currently there isn't much co=
ntrol over filtering and manipulating
these charts though we intend to move=
 to a more interactive mechanism.
 You can download your project's data as =
XML for custom analysis. You
can also explore any of the open projects to l=
earn how they are
testing. We have collected about 25 person years of testi=
ng activity
so far. This sort of 

data is so new, we are all still explori=
ng the
space to find the gems, so getting as many people involved as possib=
le
is very useful.

Here are the reports collected so far during the develo=
pment of
DevCreek itself:

https://devcreek.com/reports/projects/TestCreek/=
index.html

All of the open projects, such as DevCreek/TestCreek, are open =
to the
public for us all to learn from. Feel free to click around.

We have=
 also put together a short animation of the first nine months
of testing wh=
ile developing DevCreek. It's not a report but does
attempt to provide an a=
lternative kind of view onto the development
process.

https://community.de=
vcreek.com/space/David+Jones/blog/2007-09-10_1


If you have any questions =
about JUnit integration, or alternative
reports please ask.

Cheers
David J=
ones
